G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This is an action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, and the Massachusetts Trial Court rules, venue is proper in the Cambridge Division of the District Court Department because the Premises are located in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and the acts and omissions complained of occurred in this division.

Johnson v. Keith, 368 Mass. 316, 318\u20.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease or tenancy at will includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common law. See, e.g., Johnson v. Keith, 368 Mass. 316, 318–19 (1975).
Johnson v. Keith, 368 Mass. 316, 318\u20.support_reasoning: The Johnson v. Keith opinion reproduced here concerns the validity and enforceability of a no‑pets rule in a condominium under G.L. c. 183A; it does not discuss residential leases, tenancies at will, G.L. c. 186, § 14, or the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. There is no language establishing that every residential lease or tenancy at will contains such an implied covenant. The case is thus mis-cited for the stated proposition.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied into every residential tenancy and protects the tenant’s right to use and enjoy the leased premises without substantial interference by the landlord or those acting under the landlord’s authority. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715–18 (1977); Johnson v. Keith, 368 Mass. 316, 318–19 (1975).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes an implied covenant (warranty) of quiet enjoyment in favor of the tenants and holds that it is breached where tenants are “very substantially deprived” of the quiet enjoyment of their leased premises due to conditions the landlord created and could control. The court explains that the landlord’s conduct, even without intent, can violate this implied covenant when substantial interference with the tenant’s beneficial use and habitability is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did or permitted. That aligns with the proposition that an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential tenancies protects against substantial landlord-related interference with use and enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that the tenants were ‘very substantially deprived’ of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises ‘for a substantial time’… He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances… There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: A landlord may be liable for breach of quiet enjoyment where the landlord’s actions, or those set in motion by the landlord, substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, even if the landlord does not specifically intend the harmful result. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 718–19; Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly holds that failure to provide heat constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and that liability does not depend on the landlord’s intent but on whether the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct is an interruption of the tenant’s rights. This directly supports the proposition that a landlord may be liable for substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment even without specific intent to cause the harmful result.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ Blackett v. Olanoff, supra at 716. Thus…liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.proposition: The covenant protects against substantial interference, including recurrent or continuous noise, dust, and other disturbances that render the premises significantly less fit for ordinary residential use. See Blackett, 371 Mass. at 715–19; Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997) (construing G.L. c. 186, § 14 broadly in favor of tenants).
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.support_reasoning: Al‑Ziab does construe G.L. c. 186, § 14, but its focus is on the fault requirement (at least negligence and landlord notice) and on rejecting strict liability based solely on a lead‑paint violation. The opinion does not discuss recurrent or continuous noise, dust, or similar disturbances, nor does it articulate a standard that the covenant protects against substantial interference rendering premises significantly less fit for ordinary residential use. Those points come from other cases (e.g., Blackett), not from Al‑Ziab itself.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 282–83 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes an “act” and “omission” under G.L. c. 186, § 14, because Defendant has (a) affirmatively caused the Renovation Project to occur and (b) failed to take reasonable steps to prevent or mitigate the substantial interference with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of the Premises. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 282–83 (1994) (landlord liability for failure to take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable interference).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and holds that a landlord’s *omissions*—its failure to take reasonable, relatively easy measures to remove unlawful actors from common areas it controls—can constitute an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment. The court emphasizes that liability may arise from what the landlord "failed to do" or "permitted to be done," and remands for fact-finding on whether the landlord took adequate steps. This directly supports using Doe as authority that both affirmative conduct and failures to act can be an "act" or "omission" under § 14 when they result in substantial interference.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Landlords are responsible under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for the acts of those they introduce onto the premises, such as contractors, where those acts interfere with tenants’ quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–03 (1982); Blackett, 371 Mass. at 718–19.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses landlord responsibility under G.L. c. 186, § 14 where the immediate physical cause of the interference is the conduct of third parties. Gem argued that other tenants’ misuse of plumbing caused the flooding and was beyond its control, but the court rejected that defense, holding Gem liable under § 14 because the flooding was a preventable condition the landlord had a duty to prevent. This establishes that landlords are responsible under § 14 for interference with quiet enjoyment resulting from conditions created or allowed by those they introduce or control on the premises, such as contractors or other tenants.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “As its third objection to Solomon’s recovery on her count for interference with quiet enjoyment, Gem asserts that it was wrongly held responsible for the actions of third parties beyond its control… Gem argues that it was unable to control the source of the flooding. Cf. Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977). This contention echoes Gem’s objections to the verdict for reckless infliction of emotional distress, and we reject it for the same reasons. The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent… Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400\u.proposition: Defendant has not provided a meaningful rent abatement or comparable accommodation for the loss of use and enjoyment suffered by Plaintiff. A nominal, one-time discount of approximately $100 does not cure or waive Defendant’s liability for ongoing and substantial interference. See generally Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400–01 (1982) (discussing damages and abatement concepts in landlord–tenant disputes).
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400\u.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses how to calculate damages and rent abatement when there is substantial interference with use and enjoyment, but it does not address whether a nominal, one‑time discount (such as $100) is insufficient to cure or waive a landlord’s liability. Wolfberg instead holds that tenants are entitled to damages equal to the difference between the rental value as warranted and as defective, plus expenses, with rent withheld then subtracted, and focuses on avoiding duplicative or inadequate recovery in the context of G.L. c. 93A and c. 186, § 14. It does not speak to the legal effect of a nominal discount as a purported abatement or waiver of liability.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400\u.relevant_excerpt:
We believe that the judge erred in thus resolving the issues raised by the plaintiff’s claim for damages. There has been a substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of the apartment to which the tenants were entitled under their lease. This interference with a right guaranteed to them under their lease constitutes a loss of property to the tenants. They had a contractual right to enjoy the use of the apartment free of rodents. The judge found that the tenants withheld rent justifiably. Thus they were deprived of their contractual right by the landlord’s conduct.

… we hold, therefore, that where tenants who have withheld rent under G. L. c. 239, § 8A, or under the common law … prevail in a claim for damages under G. L. c. 93A, their damages under G. L. c. 93A shall be calculated by determining the rental value of the unit as warranted — the agreed rent — minus the value of the unit in a defective condition, plus any reasonable expenses incurred by the tenants as a result of the defective condition.

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 747–49 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: The conditions created and allowed to persist by Defendant—constant construction noise, dust infiltration, and extended disruption—substantially deprive Plaintiff of the full benefit of her bargain and materially impair the value of the Premises as a quiet and habitable residence and place of work. See Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 747–49 (2005) (recognizing recovery where conditions substantially interfere with tenancy).
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The proposition claims Jablonski recognizes recovery where conditions substantially interfere with a tenancy and materially impair the premises’ value; however, this case holds the opposite on its facts. The Appeals Court affirms findings of no breach of the warranty of habitability and no interference with quiet enjoyment, emphasizing that not every code violation or condition amounts to a material/substantial interference. While the opinion recites general standards (material and substantial breach; serious interference), it does not involve, or uphold recovery for, extensive construction-type disturbances like noise, dust, or extended disruption, and ultimately finds no such interference here.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “We have required a material and substantial breach of the warranty, representing a significant defect in the property itself, in order to excuse the tenant’s obligation to pay rent. … Not every violation of the Sanitary Code, however, will support a claim of breach of the warranty. … The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 15F.proposition: To the extent any provision of the Tenancy agreement is construed as limiting or waiving Plaintiff’s rights under G.L. c. 186, § 14, such provision would be void and unenforceable as against public policy. See G.L. c. 186, § 15F; Al‑Ziab, 424 Mass. at 850–51.

G.L. c. 93A, \u00a7 9.proposition: To the extent necessary, Plaintiff also relies on G.L. c. 93A, § 9 standards and analogous case law as persuasive authority regarding the reasonableness of landlord conduct, although Plaintiff does not assert a separate claim under G.L. c. 93A in this Complaint.
